Nashville, Tennessee, U.S. |alma_mater= [[University of Nashville]] (A. B.)
[[University of Virginia]] (LL.B.) |signature=bwalkersignature.png |signature_size =200px |module = {{Infobox college football player|embed=yes |currentposition=[[Fullback (American football)|Fullback]]/[[Tackle (American football)|Tackle]] |weight_lb=198 |height_ft=6 |height_in=3 |school=Virginia Cavaliers |highschool=Columbia |class=1902 |pastschools= *[[Nashville Garnet and Blue football|Nashville]] (1896–1897) *St. Albans (1898–1899) *[[Virginia Cavaliers football|Virginia]] (1900–1901) |highlights= *Southern championship (1900, 1901) *[[College Football All-Southern Team|All-Southern]] ([[1900 College Football All-Southern Team|1900]], [[1901 College Football All-Southern Team|1901]]) }} }} '''Bradley Walker''' (October 14, 1877 – February 3, 1951) was a [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] attorney who, in his youth, was found to be naturally proficient at virtually any sport he tried, including [[American football|football]], [[baseball]], [[Track and field|track]], [[boxing]], [[tennis]] and [[golf]]— in all these sports he either set records or won championships or awards. Walker was best known for his [[college football]] performance, playing for the [[Nashville Garnet and Blue football|University of Nashville]] in 1896 and 1897, and the [[Virginia Cavaliers football|Virginia Cavaliers]] in [[1900 Virginia Cavaliers football team|1900]] and [[1901 Virginia Cavaliers football team|1901]]. He was named to an "[[College Football All-Southern Team|All-Southern]]" team in [[1900 College Football All-Southern Team|1900]]. He also set records at Virginia in [[Virginia Cavaliers baseball|baseball]] for the highest [[batting average (baseball)|batting average]] over a two-year period. ''The Palm'' of [[Alpha Tau Omega]] called Walker "one of the all-time greats in [[Southern United States|Southern]] athletic history." Describing Walker's football ability, celebrated coach [[John Heisman]] said, "he was undoubtedly one of the twenty-five best men that [[Dixie]]land ever saw". When Walker moved to Nashville to practice law in 1903, he kept his interest in football and [[Referee (American football)|officiated]] football games, including major collegiate games, for 25 years. He was also president of the owners of the [[Nashville Vols]] baseball team for two years. He was the first president of the Nashville Tennis Club and won the local championship several times. He was the boxing champion of Nashville in 1899. Walker also won the Tennessee State Amateur Golf Championship, and won his local club championship six times, during which he became a friend and confidante of sportswriter [[Grantland Rice]] who had just begun playing the game. ==Early years== Bradley Walker was born on October 14, 1877, in [[Columbia, Tennessee|Columbia]], [[Tennessee]], near Nashville. His father was William Overton Walker, a farmer and a lumberman. His mother was Alice Cabler. His grandparents were William Walker and Elizabeth Bradley.{{cite journal|title=Walker, Bradley|url=http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015078229260;view=1up;seq=712|journal=The National Cyclopaedia of American Biography|volume=40|page=354|year = 1893}} Walker attended Columbia High School and later graduated from the [[University of Nashville]]'s [[Peabody College]]{{efn|It was called "Peabody Normal School" until 1909, when it became the "George Peabody College for Teachers".{{cite web|title=Peabody College Chronology|url=http://www.library.vanderbilt.edu/speccol/digcoll/gpcchrono.shtml|website=library.vanderbilt.edu|publisher=Vanderbilt University Special Collections|accessdate=May 20, 2018|date=December 5, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406104359/http://www.library.vanderbilt.edu/speccol/digcoll/gpcchrono.shtml|archive-date=April 6, 2016|url-status=dead}}}} with a teacher's certificate in 1897. From 1898 to 1900, he taught [[mathematics]] at St. Albans School in [[Radford, Virginia|Radford]], [[Virginia]].{{cite news|title=Bradley Walker, Attorney, Dies|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/109398266|accessdate=May 19, 2018|issue=279|publisher=The Nashville Tennessean|date=February 4, 1951|volume=44|pages=1 & 2}} ===University of Nashville=== ====Football==== Walker played at the [[Fullback (American football)|fullback]] and [[Tackle (American football)|tackle]] positions for the [[University of Nashville|Nashville football team]], known as the "[[Nashville Garnet and Blue football|Garnet and Blue]]". Nashville [[Upset (competition)|upset]] the [[1897 Sewanee Tigers football team|Sewanee]] squad by a score of 5 to 4 in 1897.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20178869/the_tennessean/|title=Dixie's Football Hall of Fame|author=J. W. Heisman|date=February 7, 1915|work=The Tennessean|accessdate=May 24, 2018|page=35|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} [[John Heisman]], coach of the [[1897 Auburn Tigers football team|Auburn]] team who had defeated Nashville 14 to 4 two weeks later, said Walker was the best football player in the school's history, saying "I have no hesitation whatever in declaring that he was undoubtedly one of the twenty-five best men that Dixieland ever saw".{{efn|In 1890, eight years before Walker was there, the Nashville Garnet and Blue challenged [[1890 Vanderbilt Commodores football team|Vanderbilt]] to a football game, but lost 40 to 0. This was the first intercollegiate game ever played in Tennessee.{{cite web|title=Vanderbilt Football Through The Years /Year-By-Year History|url=http://www.vucommodores.com/sports/m-footbl/history.html|website=vucommodores.com|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=May 22, 2018|date=November 27, 1890|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160617205820/http://www.vucommodores.com/sports/m-footbl/history.html|archive-date=June 17, 2016|url-status=dead}}}} In Heisman's words, "[Walker]... was about 6 feet 3 inches tall and he must have weighed close to 200 pounds even then...our men never seemed to see him coming until he had his gain made and was up at 'em again". ====Other sports==== Walker was also on the baseball and track teams. He received his [[Bachelor of Arts|bachelors]] degree in 1898 from the University of Nashville{{cite news|title=Commencement Day|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/119161811/?terms=%22Bradley+Walker%22+%22University+of+Nashville%22|accessdate=May 22, 2018|publisher=The Nashville American|date=May 26, 1898}} and received the school's "All-Around Athlete" medal.{{cite news |last1=Ezell |first1=Bill |title=Bradley Walker Doted on Sports |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/602997077/?terms=%22Bradley%20Walker%22&match=1 |access-date=September 30, 2023 |volume=74|issue=274 |publisher=The Nashville Banner |date=February 23, 1950 |page=36}} In 1898, Walker entered a track meet at [[Vanderbilt University|Vanderbilt]] and won the 100-yard dash with a time of 10.5 seconds; he came in second in the shot-put, the 440 yard dash, and the hammer throw.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20490660/the_tennessean/|work=The Nashville American|page=6|date=May 8, 1898|title=Annual Track Meet|accessdate=May 29, 2018|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} He was also the city [[boxing]] champion of Nashville in 1899 prior to leaving for Virginia. ===University of Virginia=== [[File:bradleywalker.jpg|thumb|160px|Walker depicted c. 1900]] ====Football==== He received his law degree at the [[University of Virginia]] in a two-year program, 1901 and 1902. Walker starred in football, baseball, and track at the University of Virginia. The Virginia team was the Southern champion in 1900 and gave the [[1900 Sewanee Tigers football team|Sewanee Tigers]] their first defeat since 1897 by a score of 17 to 5. One account of the Sewanee game reads "Bradley Walker, full-back, is the strongest and heaviest player on the team."{{cite news|work=Richmond Dispatch|url=http://virginiachronicle.com/cgi-bin/virginia?a=d&d=RD19001125.1.18#|title=Virginia vs. Sewanee|date=November 25, 1900}} In the game against the [[Carlisle Indians]] he grabbed [[Hawley Pierce]], Carlisle's biggest player, and carried him ten yards with him dangling over his shoulder.{{cite journal|title=There's No Place Like Virginia, They Say| date=September 1951 |journal=Saturday Evening Post|volume=224|issue=12|page=30|url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/19531547/theres-no-place-like-virginia-they-say|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303223047/http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/19531547/theres-no-place-like-virginia-they-say|url-status=dead|archive-date=2016-03-03}} Walker was selected All-Southern in 1900 by W. H. Hoge.{{cite journal|journal=Spalding's Football Guide|year=1901|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IQw7AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA123|page=123|title=All Southern Football Team|author=W. H. Hoge|via=[[Google books]]|accessdate=March 10, 2015}} {{Open access}} [[File:1901UVAfootball.jpg|thumb|left|220px|1901 Virginia football team]] In 1901, the Cavaliers were again the Southern champion. Walker was the star of the [[Washington and Lee Generals football|Washington and Lee]] game on opening day, called by one writer the "star football player of the South".{{Cite news|url=https://virginiachronicle.com/cgi-bin/virginia?a=d&d=T19011003.1.1&srpos=2&e=--1899---1901--en-20--1--txt-txIN-%22bradley+walker%22------|title=Varsity Won Its Opening Game|date=October 3, 1901|work=The Times|volume=16}} He scored a [[touchdown]] and kicked a 40-yard [[field goal]] in the win over rival [[1901 VPI football team|VPI]].{{Cite news|url=https://virginiachronicle.com/cgi-bin/virginia?a=d&d=T19011027.1.1&srpos=8&e=--1899---1901--en-20--1--txt-txIN-football+walker------|title=Varsity Triumphant Over Polytechnics|date=October 27, 1901|work=The Times}} [[Caspar Whitney]] ranked Walker as perhaps the best player in the South, but said he had been playing football for more than four years if one were to include his time teaching at St. Albans in Radford, and so did not pick him.{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JrBUAAAAYAAJ&q=%22outing%22+all+southern&pg=PA727|journal=Outing|title=Southern Intercollegiate Football|page=726|volume=37|last1=Whitney|first1=Caspar|year=1902}} The Virginia faithful objected, saying this was not a common reason to rule one ineligible.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2082758//|work=The Times|date=March 16, 1902|page=14|accessdate=March 27, 2015|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|title=College Gossip In Old Virginia}} {{Open access}} ''The Palm'' of [[Alpha Tau Omega]] described Walker as "one of the all-time greats in [[Southern United States|Southern]] athletic history."{{cite journal|year=1950|title=Nashville|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y8TmAAAAMAAJ&q=%22nashville+attorney%22|journal=The Palm of Alpha Tau Omega|volume=70|issue=2|page=47}} ====Baseball==== A [[third baseman]] on the baseball team, he set a record in batting at Virginia. Writing in 1950, ''Nashville Banner'' sportswriter Bill Ezell said, "[Walker] established a record that hasn't been approached since and probably never will— a batting average of .492 over a two-year period". ==Nashville== Walker was secretary of the Nashville Park Board from 1902 to 1910. He began law practice in Nashville in 1903 with the firm of Champion, Brown and Akers. For thirty years he was an attorney for his alma mater Peabody College, and also represented churches and other Tennessee colleges in legislative matters.{{cite web|url=http://dlynx.rhodes.edu/jspui/bitstream/10267/7458/3/BDMIN02041930.pdf.txt|title=OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS OF SOUTHWESTERN REIDIN THE DIRECTORS' ROOM A1R IN PATJ HALL|date=February 4, 1930}} Walker represented Tennessee Businessmen in the fight against sales tax and successfully represented merchants in opposing the use of convict labor. He was a leader in organizing the Tennessee Taxpayers Association in 1932 and served on its board for 10 years. From 1940–42, Walker was chairman of the [[Red Cross]] drive in Nashville. In 1950, he made an unsuccessful bid for state office on the State Railroad and Public Utilities Commission,{{cite news|title=Governor Slowly Piles Up Lead In Race For Nomination|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/353347302/|accessdate=May 24, 2018|agency=Associated Press|issue=184|publisher=Clarksville Leaf–Chronicle|date=August 4, 1950|volume=92|pages=1 & 9}}{{cite news|last1=Freehoff|first1=Bill|title=Demo Primary Features Run For Governor|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/30102926/?terms=%22Bradley+Walker%22+%22state+railroad+and+public+utilities+commission%22|accessdate=May 24, 2018|issue=41|publisher=Kingsport Times-News|date=July 30, 1950|volume=6|page=15–B}} but it was a race where the winner of five candidates did not have a majority. This prompted Walker (who came in second) to run again that fall, but this time for the office of commissioner, as an independent candidate in the general election, but lost to John C. Hammer.{{cite news|title=Final Returns From Tuesday Voting|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/282451874/?terms=%22Bradley+Walker%22++%22John+C.+Hammer%22|accessdate=May 24, 2018|issue=269|publisher=The Jackson Sun|date=November 9, 1950|volume = 102|page=1}} ===Football=== The [[1903 Nashville Garnet and Blue football team|1903 Nashville football team]] was disbanded, and then started back again with Walker as coach.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7955700/the_courierjournal/|title=Nashville Team Will Not Disband|work=The Courier-Journal|date=November 9, 1903|page=7|accessdate=December 21, 2016|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} After his playing days waned, Walker became interested in officiating major college football games and was awarded a "License of Efficiency" by the National Rules and Governing Body of collegiate football.{{cite news|title=Lucien Emerson Is Made Licensed Grid Official|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/178421885/?terms=%22Bradley+Walker%22+%22license%22|accessdate=May 24, 2018|issue=77|publisher=Nashville Tennessean|date=July 26, 1925|volume = 17|page=2, (Sports)}} He officiated football in the Nashville area for 25 years including many Southern football games,{{cite news|title=Football Experts Give Their Selections For An All-Southern Team|author=W. R. Tichenor|date=December 3, 1905|newspaper=The Atlanta Constitution|author-link=W. R. Tichenor}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19220927&id=SdhPAAAAIBAJ&pg=5024,3452249|title=Trying Out Golf Course|date=September 27, 1922|work=The Evening Independent}} like the [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]]–[[Vanderbilt Commodores football|Vanderbilt]] series beginning in 1907.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JHRMAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA56|title=Practical English Composition|author=Edwin Lillie Miller|volume=2|page=56|year=1916}}{{cite journal|title=Michigan 9; Vanderbilt, 8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-BTiAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA68|journal=The Michigan Alumnus|volume=18|page=68|year=1912}} ===Baseball=== In 1902, he played baseball at Highland Park (now Conger Park) in [[Jackson, Tennessee]], as a member of the Memphis Chickasaw Club.{{cite news|title=Bradley Walker, Utilities Candidate, Former Ballplayer|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/282492015/?terms=%22Bradley+Walker%22|accessdate=May 25, 2018|issue=169|publisher=The Jackson Sun|date=July 16, 1950|volume = 102|page=7}} In 1905, Walker and four other investors formed a company to raise money to field the Nashville Vols baseball team, buying the team from its original owner [[Newt Fisher]]. With Walker as president, they attempted to sell 100 shares of stock at $100 per share to support the team, but fell short of their goal. After cutting corners to remain solvent, the stock company finally placed the team up for sale in 1907.{{cite book|last1=Simpson|first1=John A.|title="The greatest game ever played in Dixie" : the Nashville Vols, their 1908 season, and the championship game|date=2007|publisher=McFarland|location=Jefferson, N.C.|isbn=978-0-7864-3050-5|page=32|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q-YyBwAAQBAJ&q=Bradley+Walker+Nashville&pg=PA32|accessdate=May 19, 2018}} This happened to be the same year that Grantland Rice became a columnist on the sports page of ''[[The Tennessean]]''.{{efn|A larger group of new investors appeared, led by [[Ferdinand E. Kuhn]], and raised $50,000. Advised by Rice, they re-structured the team's on-field management to pull the team out of last place and later began a new stadium, using the name "[[Sulphur Dell]]" which was coined by Rice.}} ===Tennis=== Walker was the first president of the Nashville Tennis Club{{cite news |last1=Morrow |first1=Libbie L. |title=Leading Social Clubs of Nashville |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/604103592/?terms=%22Nashville%20Golf%20Club%22&match=1 |access-date=September 10, 2023 |work=The Boosters' Edition, Part 2, 16 pp. |issue=32 |publisher=Nashville Banner |date=June 22, 1907 |page=5}} in 1903 and won the local championship several times.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NBNUAAAAYAAJ&q=Bradley+Walker+Nashville&pg=PA259|title=Nashville Social Directory/Tennis Club|last1=Geraldton|first1=Mrs. Wm. W.|date=1911|website=books.google.com|publisher=Cumberland Press|page=259|accessdate=May 20, 2018}} ===Golf=== [[File:Bradley Walker golf swing ca. 1913.jpg|thumb|Bradley Walker, ca. 1913]]In 1912, Walker was active in the Nashville Golf and Country Club and won the club golf championship in 1912, 1914, 1915, 1916,{{cite news|title=Bradley Walker Retains Title as Club Champion|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/118974039/?terms=%22Bradley+Walker%22|accessdate=May 21, 2018|issue=102|publisher=The Nashville Tennessean and the Nashville American|date=August 21, 1916|volume = 10|page=10}} 1919, and 1928.{{cite book|last1=Wills|first1=Ridley II|title=Belle Meade Country Club : the first 100 years|date=2001|publisher=Hillsboro Press/Providence House|location=Franklin, Tenn.|isbn=1-57736-222-5}} According to historian [[Ridley Wills II]], wooden tees had not been invented in those days, and each golfer would use sand and water to make a homemade tee. At age 37, Walker won Tennessee's first state amateur golf championship (1914). He defeated [[Charles McGhee Tyson|McGhee Tyson]]{{efn|Four years after this golf match, Charles McGhee Tyson had become a Navy pilot in World War I and was lost in a crash over the North Sea. The [[McGhee Tyson Airport|Knoxville Airport]] was named in his honor. His father was a Tennessee legislator and army general, [[Lawrence Tyson|Lawrence Davis Tyson]].{{cite web|last1=Neely|first1=Jack|title=McGhee Tyson Airport/History|url=http://tys.org/fun/history-airport.asp|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513001557/http://tys.org/fun/history-airport.asp|url-status=dead|archive-date=2008-05-13|accessdate=May 21, 2018}}}} of [[Knoxville, Tennessee|Knoxville]]. The newspaper account said, "Walker, not only a seasoned golfer of many tournaments' experience, but of athletic competitions of all kinds, bore up under the tension more ably than did the Cherokee [Country Club] finalist".{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/119539820/?terms=%22Bradley+Walker%22|title=Bradley Walker Wins the State Golf Title|date=September 13, 1914|volume=8|accessdate=May 21, 2018|publisher=The Nashville Tennessean and The Nashville American|issue=125|page=7–B}} Walker continued to compete in this same annual tournament for the next 36 years, until 1950, when he was too busy campaigning for political office.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/109398438/?terms=%22Bradley+Walker%22+%22University+of+Nashville%22|title=Mr. Bradley Walker|date=February 5, 1951|volume=44|accessdate=May 22, 2018|publisher=The Nashville Tennessean|issue=280|page=6}} Years later Walker downplayed his state amateur golf victory saying, in effect, that he did not have any skilled young players competing with him back then.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/147954873/?terms=%22Bradley+Walker%22+and+Boxing|title=Bradley Walker, First Champ, says Rise of Youngsters Biggest Change|last1=Grimsley|first1=Will|date=July 6, 1941|volume=32|accessdate=19 May 2018|publisher=The Nashville Tennessean|issue=1797|page=2–D}} During this time Grantland Rice took up the game of golf and got to know Walker at the Nashville Golf and Country Club. Rice took lessons from the club's pro Charlie Hall, hired in 1909. Rice began playing there regularly and said "I never dreamed that golf would provide so must grist for my typewriter". A few years later, Walker was in need of Rice's knowledge in order to find a golf pro after the existing pro, Samuel Aiken, died suddenly. [[Scottish people|Scottish]] golfer [[George Livingstone (golfer)|George Livingstone]] happened to hear of the situation and immediately applied for the position. Walker asked Grantland Rice to investigate Livingstone via a [[Telegraphy|telegram]], saying "...look him up and wire us". Rice's report was favorable, and Walker hired George Livingstone on May 12, 1912. Livingstone served as golf pro there for 36 years, retiring in 1948.{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Raymond|title=One Man's Opinion: Nashville's Top Sports figure? This'll Jog Your Memory|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/109400212/|accessdate=May 23, 2018|issue=235|publisher=The Nashville Tennessean|date=January 1, 1950|volume=43|pages=14 A, 17 A}} In 1914, when the club was moved to a new location, Walker served on the project committee, the golf course committee and was a long-time board member. The club moved to [[Belle Meade, Tennessee|Belle Meade]], a suburb of Nashville, and was renamed "Belle Meade Country Club" in 1921.{{cite book|last1=Sirko|first1=Kelly E., Ed.|title=Belle Meade Country Club Archives Collection|date=Jan 30, 2018|publisher=Belle Meade Country Club|location=Nashville|page=3|edition=First}} In 1916, sportswriter [[Blinkey Horn]] claimed that the golf course "has no equal in the south".{{cite news|last1=Horn|first1=Blinkey|title=Belle Meade Golf Course Is Diadem of Natural Hazards|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/118962698/?terms=%22George+Livingstone%22|accessdate=May 21, 2018|publisher=The Nashville Tennessean and the Nashville American|date=July 16, 1916|page=9}} ==Personal life== Walker married Ethel Mathews on December 17, 1903, the daughter of publisher Andrew Francis Mathews of Nashville. They had two children: Bradley Walker Jr., who died in infancy, and Ethel Walker. Ethel Walker became a pediatrician and was one of the notable alumni of the Peabody Demonstration School (later [[University School of Nashville]]).{{cite news|last1=Shoulders|first1=Carolyn|title=Peabody School's Ethel Walker: She's Doctored 3 Generations|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/112427001|accessdate=May 24, 2018|issue=72|publisher=The Tennessean|date=May 23, 1985|volume=80|pages=1–A, 11–A}} The Walker family had a summer home at [[Monteagle, Tennessee|Monteagle]] Assembly Grounds.{{cite news|title=Nashville Society is Spending Fourth Here There and Everywhere|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/178768608|accessdate=May 24, 2018|issue=54|publisher=Nashville Tennessean|date=July 4, 1926|volume=18|pages=1, 3 (Woman's Section)}} Walker died February 3, 1951, in his apartment at 3415 West End Avenue in Nashville. He had collapsed in his automobile a few minutes earlier, with his daughter, Dr. Ethel Walker, in attendance. A cerebral hemorrhage was suspected. The service was at West End Methodist Church. He was buried at [[Mount Olivet Cemetery (Nashville)|Mount Olivet Cemetery]].{{cite news|title=Bradley Walker Dies in Nashville|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/353373641/?terms=%22Bradley+Walker%22|accessdate=May 19, 2018|issue=31|publisher=The Leaf-Chronicle (Clarksville, Tennessee)|date=February 6, 1951|volume = 143|page=5}} Walker was a [[methodist]], and politically a [[Democratic Party (United States)|democrat]]. He was a [[Freemasonry|32nd degree Mason]], a member of [[Order of the Eastern Star|Eastern Star]] and served as district governor of the Tennessee [[National Exchange Club|Exchange Club]]. He was a member of [[Alpha Tau Omega]] social fraternity and a member of the [[Sons of Confederate Veterans]]. == Notes == {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Nashville Garnet and Blue football coach navbox}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Walker, Bradley}} [[Category:1877 births]] [[Category:1951 deaths]] [[Category:American football fullbacks]] [[Category:American football punters]] [[Category:American football tackles]] [[Category:College football officials]] [[Category:Virginia Cavaliers football players]] [[Category:All-Southern college football players]] [[Category:University of Nashville alumni]] [[Category:University of Virginia School of Law alumni]] [[Category:Peabody College alumni]] [[Category:Tennessee Democrats]] [[Category:People from Columbia, Tennessee]] [[Category:Sportspeople from the Nashville metropolitan area]] [[Category:Baseball players from Nashville, Tennessee]] [[Category:Players of American football from Nashville, Tennessee]] [[Category:Methodists from Tennessee]] [[Category:Virginia Cavaliers baseball players]] [[Category:Golfers from Tennessee]] [[Category:Boxers from Tennessee]] [[Category:American male tennis players]] [[Category:Virginia Cavaliers men's track and field athletes]] [[Category:Tennessee lawyers]] [[Category:Baseball third basemen]] [[Category:Members of Sons of Confederate Veterans]]

{{Short description|American country vocalist}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Bradley Walker | landscape = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1978 | birth_place = [[Athens, Alabama]] | occupation = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter}} | origin = | genre = [[Country music|Country]], [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]] | years_active = 1998–present | label = [[Gaither Music Group]] | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|bradleywalker.com}} }} '''Bradley Walker''' is an American [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] and [[country music]] singer and songwriter. ==Early life== Bradley Walker is a native of [[Athens, Alabama]]. He was born with [[muscular dystrophy]], and has been in a wheelchair all his life. He was a student at [[Limestone County School District|East Limestone High School]] where he played percussion in the school band.{{cite news |url=http://archive.decaturdaily.com/decaturdaily/news/060721/walker.shtml |title=Riding on a 'Highway of Dreams' |first= Holly|last= Hollman |work=The Decatur Daily |date=July 21, 2006 }} Walker started singing when he was two or three years old, and began performing in public when he was four.{{cite news |url=http://www.waff.com/story/13305350/overcoming-the-odds-country-singer-lives-out-his-dreams |title=Overcoming the Odds: Country singer lives out his dreams |first=Kimberly|last= Essex |work=WAFF48 }} When he was ten, he was invited on stage to perform with [[The Oak Ridge Boys]], and when he was eleven, he sang with The Oak Ridge Boys on [[The Nashville Network]]'s [[Nashville Now]] as well as on the [[The Jerry Lewis MDA Labor Day Telethon|Jerry Lewis MDA Telethon]].{{cite web |url=http://americanprofile.com/articles/singer-bradley-walker/ |title=Singer Thrives Despite Disease |first= Michael|last= McCall |date=January 20, 2008 |work=American Profile }} He works at the [[Browns Ferry Nuclear Power Plant]] as a Material Inventory Coordinator while pursuing a music career. ==Music career== In 1998, Walker formed a band, The Trinity Mountain Boys, and began to perform at bluegrass festivals. In 2001, he joined the Georgia-based group Lost Horizon.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/297056/bradley-walker/biography |title=Bradley Walker > Biography |magazine=Billboard |access-date=2016-11-13 |archive-date=2016-11-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161129220949/http://www.billboard.com/artist/297056/bradley-walker/biography |url-status=dead }} He was signed to [[Rounder Records]], and released his debut album, ''Highway of Dreams'', in 2006. The album was produced by [[Carl Jackson]].{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=6955339 |title='Highway of Dreams' for Singer Bradley Walker|date=January 23, 2007 |work=NPR}} For his performance on the album, he won the Male Vocalist of the Year Award from the [[International Bluegrass Music Association]]. ===2016: ''Call Me Old-Fashioned''=== Walker's second album, ''Call Me Old-Fashioned'', was produced by [[Rory Feek]] and recorded at the [[Joey + Rory]] studio out on their farm. Walker had known Joey and Rory Feek since 2007, and he was asked by Rory Feek to sing the hymn "[[Leave It There]]" at the funeral of [[Joey Feek]] in accordance with her wishes.{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/features/bradley-walker-on-joey-feeks-influence-behind-new-album-w445844 |title=Bradley Walker on Joey Feek's Influence Behind New Album |magazine= Rolling Stone |first=Deborah |last=Evans Price|date=October 20, 2016 }} [[Bill Gaither (gospel singer)|Bill Gaither]] of the [[Gaither Music Group]], who was also at the funeral service, heard Walker's performance and signed Walker to his label.{{cite news |url=http://www.gospelherald.com/articles/67436/20161021/christian-artist-born-with-muscular-dystrophy-discusses-faith-influence-of-rory-and-joey-feek-album-call-me-old-fashioned.htm |title=Christian Artist Born with Muscular Dystrophy Discusses Faith, Influence of Rory and Joey Feek, Album 'Call Me Old-Fashioned' |first=Leah Marianne |last=Klett|date= October 21, 2016|work=Gospel Herald }} The album includes a posthumous duet with Joey Feek, "In The Time That You Gave Me", using vocals she recorded before her death. The album was released on September 23, 2016,{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/call-me-old-fashioned-mw0002974140 |title=Call Me Old-Fashioned |first=Mark |last=Deming |work=AllMusic }} and debuted at No. 9 on the Top Country Albums chart.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/7550131/bradley-walker-call-me-old-fashioned-album-joey-rory-show|title=Bradley Walker Reflects on His Surprise Top 10 Country Album & Singing at Joey Feek's Funeral |date=October 25, 2016 |first= Chuck |last=Dauphin |magazine=Billboard }} ===2017–19: ''Blessed: Hymns & Songs of Faith'' === On October 6, 2017, Walker released ''Blessed: Hymns & Songs of Faith''. The album, produced by Ben Isaacs, features collaborations with [[Vince Gill]], [[Alison Krauss]], [[Rhonda Vincent]], [[Jimmy Fortune]], [[The Oak Ridge Boys]], [[The Isaacs]] and [[Ricky Skaggs]].{{cite web |url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwmusic/article/Blessed-Hymns-and-Songs-of-Faith-by-Bradley-Walker-ft-Alison-Krauss-More-Out-Now-20171006 |title='Blessed: Hymns and Songs of Faith' by Bradley Walker ft, Alison Krauss & More Out Now|date=October 6, 2017 |work = Music World.com }} The album received a [[GMA Dove Award]] for the Bluegrass/Country/Roots Album of the Year in 2018. He also performed a song "Leave It There" in the Homecoming CD/DVD release ''Give the World A Smile'' in 2017.{{cite web |url= https://www.gastongazette.com/entertainment/20170406/bill-and-gloria-gaither-share-2-new-homecoming-albums|title=Bill and Gloria Gaither share 2 new 'Homecoming' albums |work=Gaston Gazette |first=Wade |last=Allen |date= April 6, 2017}} Walker appeared at the [[Crossroads Guitar Festival 2019]] alongside Vince Gill.[https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/eric-clapton-2019-crossroads-festival-live-album-1065415/ Eric Clapton’s 2019 Crossroads Fest Set for Live LP/Concert Film Release ] ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', September 23, 2020. Retrieved 11 October 2021 ===2020–present: Brothers of the Heart=== In 2020, Walker collaborated with [[Jimmy Fortune]], Ben Isaacs, and Mike Rogers to release an album ''Brotherly Love'' and a concert DVD/TV special filmed at Rory Feek's barn/studio near Columbia, TN.{{cite web|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/jimmy-fortune-isaacs-rogers-walker-elizabeth-premiere/ |title=Jimmy Fortune, Ben Isaacs, Mike Rogers and Bradley Walker Deliver New Take on Statlers' Classic 'Elizabeth' |first= Deborah |last= Evans Price|date= September 18, 2020|work=Sounds Like Nashville }} The album was released digitally on May 29, 2020, and the DVD and CD released on September 4, 2020.{{cite web |url=https://www.thechristianbeat.org/index.php/new-music/8383-jimmy-fortune-bradley-walker-mike-rogers-ben-isaacs-release-gaither-music-group-cd-dvd-tv-special |title=Jimmy Fortune, Bradley Walker, Mike Rogers & Ben Isaacs Release Gaither Music Group CD, DVD & TV Special |date= September 3, 2020 |first= Herb |last=Longs|work=The Christian Beat }} The concert film aired on the [[Circle (TV network)|Circle]] network on October 20, 2020.{{cite web|url=https://www.thechristianbeat.org/index.php/news/8725-gaither-music-group-s-brotherly-love-premieres-on-circle-network |title=Gaither Music Group's 'Brotherly Love' Premieres On Circle Network |date= October 20, 2020 |first= Herb |last=Longs |work=The Christian Beat}} The collaboration was successful and they decided to continue with another project, and while they were recording their second album they named their group Brothers of the Heart.{{cite web |url=https://www.ccmmagazine.com/ccm-cafe/a-conversation-with-brothers-of-the-heart-fortune-walker-rogers-isaacs/ |title=A Conversation with Brothers of the Heart (Fortune, Walker, Rogers, Isaacs) |first= Brandon |last=Woolum |date= February 10, 2023 |work=CCM Magazine}} In February 2023, Brothers of the Heart released the second album, ''Listen To The Music''. The album reached No. 5 on the Top Christian Albums chart, and No. 32 on Top Album Sales.{{cite web |url=https://todayschristianent.com/music-news-brothers-of-the-heart-to-perform-on-the-opry-feb-7-listen-to-the-music-hits-1-on-billboard-christian-album-chart/ |title= Music News: Brothers of the Heart to perform on The Opry Feb. 7; 'Listen To The Music' hits #1 on Billboard Christian album chart |work=Today Christian Entertainment }} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:12em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:17em;"| Album details ! colspan="4"| Peak chart positions ! rowspan="2" style="width:9em;"| Sales |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="45"| [[Billboard 200|US]]
